properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-29T00:44:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-28T16:25:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2961496247.2019
Area: Thebacha Region including Ft. Smith - Salt River Reserve, Ft. Resolution Region including Hwy. 6
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A pacific weather system is expected to bring heavy snow to portions of southwestern Alberta. Overnight tonight and through the day on Sunday, strong easterly winds will combine with the falling snow to produce reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Total snowfall accumulations are expected to be between 20 to 40 centimetres before the snow ends on Monday. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Road closures are possible. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-29T13:29:15-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: In addition to the 15 to 30 cm of snow received Friday night and today, Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass can expect a further 5 to 15 cm tonight and Sunday. Total accumulation for this storm could approach 50 cm. Snow level remains near 1000 metres. A return to drier conditions and more seasonal temperatures is expected early next week. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-29T13:42:39-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-28T21:43:39-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4191064734.2019
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A pacific weather system will continue to bring snow into the Calgary region with heavy snow moving into the city on Sunday. Snowfall totals are expected to reach 15 to 25 cm before the snow tapers off on Monday afternoon. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-29T13:30:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-28T21:31:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2373374154.2019
Area: City of Calgary
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: The first significant snowfall of the season will continue tonight and persist through Monday for the Foothills and much of Southern Alberta. Snow falling along the foothills and over southern Alberta will continue to spread northward overnight and into Sunday. The highest accumulations are expected to remain along the foothills, Mountain Parks and near the international border. Snowfall accumulations to the north and west of Calgary could see near 10 to 15 cm of snow before the system moves out of the province on Monday. Poor driving conditions throughout the weekend can be expected in southwestern Alberta, including portions of Highway 1 and the QEII. Heavy wet snow may cause tree branches to break. Wet snow may also cause power outages. This is expected to be a long duration event, with snow tapering off by Monday afternoon. Temperatures are forecast to rebound into the low-mid teens by mid-week, making this brief brush with winter just that...brief. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-29T14:03:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-28T22:04:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1822994054.2019

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. An intense low pressure system over the northwestern United States will slowly work its way northeastward and spread snow over southwestern Saskatchewan. The snow has begun in the southwest corner of the province this morning and will work its way northeast, reaching Moose Jaw and Regina some time tonight. By the time it gets to Regina, precipitation will be mainly in the form of rain. The worst conditions will be south of Swift Current and west of Assiniboia overnight and throughout the day on Sunday where snow and blowing snow will give significantly reduced visibilities. The snow will continue pushing northeast towards the Outlook and Humboldt regions Sunday night. A winter storm watch is also in effect for the Leader, Swift Current, and Moose Jaw regions as the worst conditions will arrive there a bit later. Total snowfalls could reach 30 cm near the Cypress Hills, with amounts gradually lessening as you go north and east. Areas south and east of Regina will have either rain or mixed precipitation, while areas north of Saskatoon will escape the brunt of the system. Please listen for updated watches and warnings as this system moves in over the next day or so. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-29T08:51:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-28T16:52:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0642574184.2019

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. An intense low pressure system over the northwestern United States is slowly working its way northeastward spreading snow over southwestern Saskatchewan. As of mid-afternoon the snow has spread into the southwest corner of the province and will work its way northeast, reaching Moose Jaw and Regina some time tonight. By the time it gets to Regina, precipitation will be mainly in the form of rain...at least until Sunday evening, when wet snowfall accumulation is likely in the city. The worst conditions will be south of Swift Current and west of Assiniboia overnight and throughout the day on Sunday where snow and blowing snow will give significantly reduced visibilities. The snow will continue pushing northeast towards the Outlook and Humboldt regions Sunday night. Total snowfalls could exceed 30 cm near the Cypress Hills, with amounts gradually lessening as you go north and east. Areas south and east of Regina will have either rain or mixed precipitation, while areas north of Saskatoon will escape the brunt of the system. Saskatoon itself will likely see some snowfall accumulations Sunday evening. Please listen for updated watches and warnings as this system develops. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-29T13:33:31-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-28T21:34:31-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2990225994.2019

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Heavy snowfall will continue over southwestern Alberta tonight. With continued upslope flow through the weekend, most regions will see significant amounts of snowfall. Total accumulations will approach 40 to 50 centimetres by Monday morning with extreme southwestern portions of Alberta possibly approaching 100 centimetres. The snowfall will taper off during the day Monday when the snow moves into Saskatchewan. As of 9:30 AM 30 cm of snow has been reported in the Crowsnest region. Heavy wet snow may cause local power outages. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Road closures are possible. Heavy snowfall accumulation may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-29T13:25:52-00:00

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Overnight temperatures across Alberta are expected to drop below 0 degrees celsius overnight leading to widespread frost. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: An intense low pressure system over the northwestern United States will slowly work its way northeastward and spread snow over southwestern Saskatchewan. The snow has begun in the southwest corner of the province this morning and will work its way northeast, reaching Moose Jaw and Regina some time tonight. By the time it gets to Regina, precipitation will be mainly in the form of rain. The worst conditions will be south of Swift Current and west of Assiniboia overnight and throughout the day on Sunday where snow and blowing snow will give significantly reduced visibilities. The snow will continue pushing northeast towards the Outlook and Humboldt regions Sunday night with the snow there continuing into Monday. A winter storm warning is in effect for the Shaunavon and Assiniboia regions where this event will begin today. This watch may also be upgraded to a warning later today as the system pushes into the area. Total snowfalls of 15 to 25 cm are possible, with up to 30 cm near the Cypress Hills. Areas south and east of Regina will have either rain or mixed precipitation, while areas north of Saskatoon will escape the brunt of the system. Please listen for updated watches and warnings as they may be expanded to neighbouring regions as the system moves in. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-29T08:52:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-28T16:53:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2674228811.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High elevation snow continues over the southern highway passes. Snow levels remain about 1000 metres and snow is expected over the highway passes tonight and Sunday. Flurries will continue on Coquihalla Highway, Allison Pass and Pennask Summit. Lower elevation areas along the BC - Alberta border are expected to see snow as well. In the Elk Valley, snow is expected to pick up tonight and persist through Sunday. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are anticipated by Sunday evening with the highest amounts closer to the Alberta border and near the community of Sparwood. Drier conditions and seasonal temperatures are expected early next week. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-29T13:44:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-28T21:45:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3094623887.2019
Area: Elk Valley
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. Significant snowfall will begin over the Cypress Hills this evening. Snowfall accumulations of 20 to 30 cm are forecast before the snow tapers off during the day Monday. The snow is likely to be wet and heavy and may cause power outages. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Heavy snowfall accumulation may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-29T08:35:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-09-28T16:36:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2458326949.2019

Description: High elevation snow continues over the southern highway passes. Snow levels remain about 1000 metres and snow is expected over the highway passes tonight and Sunday. Flurries will continue on Coquihalla Highway, Allison Pass and Pennask Summit. Lower elevation areas along the BC - Alberta border are expected to see snow as well. In the Elk Valley, snow is expected to pick up tonight and persist through Sunday. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are anticipated by Sunday evening with the highest amounts closer to the Alberta border and near the community of Sparwood. Drier conditions and seasonal temperatures are expected early next week. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Heavy snowfall will continue to intensify over southwestern Alberta today. With continued upslope flow through the weekend, most regions will see significant amounts of snowfall. Total accumulations will approach 40 to 50 cm by Monday morning with some localities reaching 70 cm. The snowfall will taper off during the day Monday when the snow moves into Saskatchewan. Heavy wet snow may cause local power outages. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Road closures are possible. Heavy snowfall accumulation may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-29T02:40:34-00:00

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage some crops in frost-prone areas. Clear or clearing skies will allow temperatures to fall below zero this evening or overnight. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-09-29T12:38:53-00:00
